As mentioned earlier, for example, it has allowed operators to fork Android.
While this strategy might change in the future if Android becomes dominant, this suggests that it is not pursuing a textbook platform strategy.
Though the iOS devices allow users to access the entire Internet, the hardware exists in a closed platform of iTunes and the App Store.
Banishing Adobe, a very important complementor, from the iPhone world drove a neutral party with enormous software capabilities toward the Android world.

Whether or not it is true that Flash would have allowed software vendors to sell directly to iPhone users and not be forced to go through the Apple App's store (Copeland 2010), it created an instant and unforeseen ally for Android.
In the U.S., Nokia had little market share, so when Google offered Android, the carriers and the phone makers felt a strong economic pressure to adopt as they needed a response to the iPhone.
Windows Mobile was inferior to Android and appeared more costly.
9 In many respects, for other members of the mobile telephony ecosystem, Android was the only viable choice-despite the fact that they feared it would commoditize their network.
Moreover, since Google generates revenues through advertisements, it can share these ad revenues with carriers, thereby giving them a stake in encouraging more Android phones to use their network.
Recently, Apple has offered other carriers their own iPhones, a necessary response, as the other carriers were becoming all Android operations.
Android provides an increasingly attractive platform upon which applications can be built, thereby competing for developer attention with Apple.

The Android business model also provides a platform that is not directly controlled by Google, thereby separating it from direct responsibility for the types of applications developed, but also suggesting that Google is unlikely to directly compete with third-party applications.
The Android challenge is asymmetric because Google is agnostic in almost all directions.
The Android platform encourages new entrants of all sorts, and the seriousness of the challenge to both Nokia and Apple is clear.
Only 2 years ago, the Nokia/Symbian global smartphone market share was enormous, but as Table 3 indicates it is rapidly losing market share.

While Cusumano and Yoffie (1998) analyzed Microsoft's defeat of Netscape in web browsers, what they could not foresee was that Microsoft would be unable to use Internet Explorer to extract greater value from the Internet.
Interestingly, with the release of the Chrome browser, Google appears to have turned on Mozilla.

Google Scholar has gained a place in basic or back-up literature search algorithms for its comprehensive coverage of information across multiple disciplines, publishing formats and languages, as well for its simplistic approach to literature searches (14).
Searches through Google Scholar are not linked to an organised vocabulary of scholarly keywords, and therefore do not require expert searching skills.

Though  Google Scholar's indexing criteria and list of covered periodicals have not been publicised, it is well known that the chances of being indexed and retrieved through the search engine increase with increasing citations and web links to the scholarly articles and web-pages of the periodicals.
The more an item is cited and downloaded, the higher its rank in the  Google Scholar's ranking algorithm.
Similar to WoS and Scopus,  Google Scholar has a 'cited by' function to track citations of the indexed sources and calculate the h index for individual researchers.
Unlike WoS and Scopus, no journal performance indicator, similar to JIF or SJR, is calculated by  Google Scholar.
